If, exceptionally, the judge wishes to hear further submissions on the draft form before approval, those submissions can be requested. Unilateral further submissions to the Court as to the order are restricted. [Section 5. Case management in the TCC, 5.9 Drawing Up of Orders (p. 41)]

question: A judgment creditor obtains a judgment in the Technology and Construction Court and applies for a charging order over the judgment debtor's property under CPR 73.3 and 73.4 using Form N379, identifying the judgment and the property. The court, after an initial hearing, can make an interim charging order imposing a charge over the debtor's interest in the property and fixing a separate hearing to determine whether to make the charging order final. The interim charging order must be served in accordance with CPR 73.7. If the judgment debtor (or any other person) objects to the making of a final charging order, he must state his objection under CPR 73.10, and there will be a hearing at which the court decides whether to make the charging order final. If the judgment remains unsatisfied, the party with the final charging order may seek an order for sale of the property under CPR 73.10C. There is reference in PD 73 paragraph 4.2 that such a claim for sale ought to be started in the Chancery Division, but the rule itself contains no such restriction, and practical difficulties have arisen for parties who have obtained a judgment, an interim charging order and a final charging order in the TCC and who do not wish to transfer to another division. The Technology and Construction Court will, in appropriate circumstances and pursuant to the overriding objective, order sale where it is appropriate and cost-effective, particularly if the parties are agreed that is the most convenient course (as in Packman Lucas Limited v Mentmore Towers Ltd [2010] EWHC 1037 (TCC)).  In light of this framework, explain: (i) the three-stage charging order process (including Form N379 and the roles of the interim and final charging orders); (ii) the service requirement for the interim order and the procedure for objections leading to a final hearing; (iii) the conditions under which an interim order may become final and the procedure for moving to an order for sale; (iv) how the TCC may exercise jurisdiction to grant an order for sale notwithstanding the PD 73.4.2 guidance, including the relevant authority and considerations highlighted in Packman Lucas; and (v) the significance of the incomplete 17.5.5 heading and how its contemplated content would interact with the above process. Your explanation should be precise and grounded in the text, using appropriate UK legal terminology and ending with the required citation.
truth: The enforceable charging-order path proceeds in three stages under CPR 73, as described in the text. First, the judgment creditor applies to the Technology and Construction Court (TCC) for a charging order under CPR 73.3 and 73.4, using Form N379 which must identify the judgment and the property concerned. The application is initially dealt with by the judge without a hearing, and the judge may make an interim charging order imposing a charge over the judgment debtor’s interest in the property and fix a hearing to consider whether to make the charging order final (stage 1). Second, the interim charging order must be served in accordance with CPR 73.7. If the judgment debtor or any other person objects to the making of a final charging order, the objection must be set out in accordance with CPR 73.10, and there will be a hearing at which the court will decide whether or not to make the charging order final (stage 2). Third, if the judgment remains unsatisfied, the holder of the final charging order may seek an order for the sale of the property under CPR 73.10C (stage 3). The text notes a potential procedural tension with PD 73 paragraph 4.2, which suggests that a claim for an order for sale to enforce a charging order should be started in the Chancery Division; however, the rule itself contains no such division restriction, and practical difficulties have arisen where judgments, interim charging orders, and final charging orders have been pursued in the TCC without transferring to another division (thus enabling a sale to be sought in the TCC where appropriate). Packman Lucas Limited v Mentmore Towers Ltd [2010] EWHC 1037 (TCC) is cited as supporting that the TCC may order sale in appropriate circumstances where it is the most convenient and cost-effective course, particularly where the parties agree. The 17.5.5 heading is truncated in the provided extract, but it signals the court’s exercise of discretion in deciding whether provisions such as a final charging order or an order for sale should be granted, likely guided by the overriding objective. Accordingly, a practitioner should consider: (i) the three-stage charging-order process and the use of Form N379; (ii) service and objections under CPR 73.7 and 73.10 and the consequent hearing for finality; (iii) the transition from interim to final charging order and the procedure for obtaining an order for sale under CPR 73.10C; (iv) the permissible scope for the TCC to grant an order for sale notwithstanding PD 73.4.2, relying on the rule’s lack of division restriction and the Packman Lucas approach; and (v) the likely considerations that would fill the gap in 17.5.5, namely, the court’s discretion under the overriding objective when deciding whether a final charging order or sale is appropriate. The answer remains grounded in the statutory and procedural framework described in the text and acknowledges the competing guidance from PD 73 and the practical authorities cited. [Section 17. Enforcement, 17.5 Charging Orders and Orders For Sale (p. 109)]

question: According to Section 8.1 General of the Technology and Construction Court guidance, set out: (i) the purpose and potential benefits of Preliminary Issues (PI) hearings; (ii) the procedural prerequisites and timing for seeking and making a PI order (including the role of the first CMC and the requirement that defence be served, subject to 8.5); (iii) how the court and parties should approach PI applications (including the possibility for a PI order to be made with the support of all parties); (iv) the role of the criteria in paragraph 8.2 in deciding suitability; and (v) the drawbacks of PI in inappropriate cases as listed.
truth: A Preliminary Issues (PI) hearing in the Technology and Construction Court is a hearing at which the Court considers and delivers a binding judgment on particular issues in advance of the main trial. It can be extremely cost-effective and efficient, narrowing the issues between the parties and, in certain cases, resolving disputes altogether (8.1.1). PI hearings are particularly well suited to cases that can be resolved on specific points and may be decisive of the proceedings; even if not decisive, a PI can significantly reduce the scope and costs of the main trial (8.1.2). At the first Case Management Conference (CMC), the Court will expect submissions on whether there are matters that should be taken by way of Preliminary Issues in advance of the main trial (8.1.3). Generally, it is not appropriate to order the trial of preliminary issues until after the defence has been served, subject to paragraph 8.5 (8.1.3). After the first CMC, and at any time during the litigation, any party may raise with any other party the possibility of a PI hearing, and the Court will consider any application for a PI hearing; in many cases, although not invariably, a PI order will be made with the support of all parties (8.1.3). While hard and fast rules cannot be set, the criteria set out in paragraph 8.2 should assist the parties in deciding whether some or all disputes are suitable for a PI hearing (8.1.4). Drawbacks of PI in inappropriate cases include: (a) evidence may be duplicated; (b) the same witnesses may give evidence before different judges if there is a switch of assigned judge; and (c) findings may be made at the PI hearing (8.1.5). [Section 8. Preliminary issues, 8.1 General (p. 59)]

question: In a construction arbitration yielding two separate awards issued at different times, if an application is brought under both awards, what is the required handling of the second or subsequent applications under Section 10.6? Additionally, outline the requirements and process for an application for permission to enforce an arbitration award without notice under Section 10.7, including (i) filing method, (ii) evidentiary requirements and draft order, (iii) the effect of a without-notice order on the time to apply to set aside, and (iv) any discretionary directions the judge may make regarding service on specified parties.
truth: Under Section 10.6, where two or more awards exist and a second or subsequent arbitration application arises under more than one award, the second or subsequent application must be referred to the same judge who heard the previous applications. If more than one judge has heard previous applications, the court should be asked to direct to which judge any subsequent application is to be referred. For enforcement of arbitration awards, Section 10.7 provides that all applications for permission to enforce are governed by Section III of Part 62 (rules 62.17-62.19). An enforcement application may be made in an arbitration claim form without notice, provided it is supported by written evidence in accordance with CPR 62.18(6), and must be accompanied by two copies of the draft order, with the form of the order sought corresponding to the terms of the award. An order made without notice giving permission to enforce must give the defendant 14 days after service of the order (or longer if the order is to be served outside the jurisdiction) to apply to set it aside, and must state that it may not be enforced until after the expiry of the 14 days (or any longer period specified) or until any application to set aside has been finally disposed of: CPR 62.18(9) and (10). On considering an application to enforce without notice, the judge may direct that, instead, the arbitration claim form must be served on specified parties, with the result that the arbitration claim form must be served on specified parties. [Section 10. Arbitration, 10.6 Successive awards and successive applications (p. 73)]

question: What are the procedural requirements for requests for further information under Section 5.5.2 in relation to a party's statement of case, specifically regarding (i) timing before the first CMC, (ii) the permissible scope of requests, and (iii) the required format for presenting the requests and their replies?
truth: The requests should, if possible, be formulated prior to the first Case Management Conference (CMC) so that they can be considered on that occasion. All requests for further information should be kept within reasonable limits, and concentrate on the important parts of the case. The requests and the replies should always be set out in one composite document, with each reply appearing immediately after each request. [Section 5. Case management in the TCC, 5.5.2 Further Information (p. 0)]

question: According to Section 1.1 of the Technology and Construction Court Guide, how is the relationship between the Guide and the Civil Procedural Rules (CPR) described, what is the Guide’s intended purpose and approach to managing TCC litigation, and what are the potential sanctions if parties fail to comply with its expectations?
truth: The TCC Guide is intended to provide straightforward, practical guidance on the conduct of litigation in the TCC, and while it is designed to be comprehensive, it does not cover all procedural points and should be seen as guidance to be adopted flexibly and adapted to the particular case; it does not substitute or override the Civil Procedural Rules (CPR) or the relevant practice directions, and it is not the function of the Guide to provide legal advice. The Guide is designed to ensure effective management of proceedings and requires the cooperation of the parties, their solicitors and counsel, who are expected to follow both the letter and the spirit of the Guide; if parties act unreasonably or fail to comply with these requirements, the court may impose sanctions including orders for costs. Parties and their advisors are expected to familiarise themselves with the CPR and, in particular, to understand the overriding objective at CPR 1.1; the Guide seeks to ensure that all cases are dealt with justly and at proportionate cost, including ensuring equality of footing, taking practicable steps to save expenditure, dealing with the dispute in ways proportionate to the size of the claim and cross-claim and its importance, and managing the case with regard to its complexity and the differing financial positions of the parties, with expedition and an appropriate share of the court’s resources. The Court also expects the parties to observe the overriding objective and to conduct litigation efficiently, at proportionate cost and without rancour or aggressive correspondence, as illustrated in Gotch v Enelco [2015] EWHC 1802 (TCC). These provisions collectively indicate that the Guide is guidance to be used flexibly rather than as rigid rules, with potential sanctions for non-compliance. [Section 1. Introduction, 1.1 Purpose of Guide (p. 1)]

question: Under Section 12.2.2 Reluctant witness, what procedural steps must a party take when a witness is unwilling, not permitted, or unavailable to provide a witness statement before trial, and what is the procedure if the party intends to rely on hearsay or the contents of documents without a witness statement, as described in Section 12.2.3 Hearsay?
truth: If a witness is unwilling, not permitted, or unavailable to provide a witness statement before trial, the party seeking to adduce the evidence should comply with CPR 32.9, which concerns the provision of witness summaries. If a party intends to rely on hearsay evidence or the contents of documents without serving a witness statement from their maker or the originator of the evidence contained in those documents, the appropriate procedure is CPR 33.1–33.5 (notice of intention to rely on hearsay or the contents of documents without a witness statement). [Section 12. Witness statements and factual evidence for use at trial, 12.2.2 Reluctant witness (p. 0)]

question: Identify the categories of disputes for which the Technology and Construction Court may hear applications for declaratory relief arising out of the commencement of a disputed adjudication, and outline the procedural steps the court will typically take, including the urgency-driven directions and the cautions regarding mislabeling an application as an 'adjudication application' to obtain expedited treatment.
truth: The Technology and Construction Court may hear applications for declaratory relief arising out of the commencement of a disputed adjudication in at least the following categories: (i) disputes over the jurisdiction of an adjudicator; (ii) disputes over whether there is a construction contract within the meaning of the Act (and, in older contracts, whether there was a written contract between the parties); and (iii) disputes over the permissible scope of the adjudication, particularly whether the matters sought to be raised are the subject of a pre-existing dispute between the parties. When such an application is brought, it will be immediately assigned to a named judge. Given the probable urgency, the judge will usually require the parties to attend a directions hearing within 2 working days of the assignment and will then give the necessary directions to ensure the speedy resolution of the dispute. However, the guidance is not absolute: the examples in 9.4.1 are not exclusive, and not all applications with some connection to an adjudication will be heard with the abbreviated timescales applicable to adjudication enforcement. The label of 'an adjudication application' should not be used to obtain an expedited hearing (for example of a Part 8 claim for declaratory relief) where there is no other justification for an expedited hearing, and a judge may refuse to hear a claim or application that has been given this label in an attempt to jump the queue. [Section 9. Adjudication business, 9.4 Other Proceedings Arising Out Of Adjudication (p. 67)]

question: According to the Technology and Construction Court guidance in Section 8. Preliminary issues, 8.2.2 Oral Evidence, what are the recommended maximum durations for a PI hearing in smaller versus larger and more complex cases, and what is the consequence if extensive oral evidence is required on a proposed PI?
truth: A PI hearing in a smaller case should not take more than about 2 days, while in a larger and more complex case it should not take more than about 4 days. If extensive oral evidence is required on any proposed PI, then it may not be suitable for a PI hearing. [Section 8. Preliminary issues, 8.2.2 Oral Evidence (p. 0)]

question: According to Section 17.1.1, what categories of decisions fall within the Technology and Construction Court's enforcement remit, and where in the document are the separate enforcement regimes for adjudication and arbitration located?
truth: The Technology and Construction Court is concerned with enforcing judgments and orders made by the TCC, and with enforcing adjudicators' decisions and arbitrators' awards. It states that adjudication enforcement is dealt with in Section 9 and arbitration enforcement in Section 10 above. [Section 17. Enforcement, 17.1 General (p. 108)]

question: Explain the procedural obligations under 6.3 and 6.4 of the Patents Court 'Statements of case (p. 3)' when a remedy sought would affect an entry in the UK Patent Register. Specifically, identify (a) the documents that must be served on the Comptroller-General of Patents, Designs and Trademarks under Part 63.14(3), and (b) the timing requirement imposed by PD63.14.1 for serving the order on the Comptroller when such an order is made. Also describe the patentee's duty if validity of the patent is challenged under 6.4.
truth: Under Part 63.14(3), where a remedy sought would, if granted, affect an entry in the United Kingdom Patent Register, the party must serve on the Comptroller-General of Patents, Designs and Trademarks: the claim form, the counterclaim or application notice; any other relevant statement of case such as grounds of invalidity (including any amended statement of case); and any accompanying documents. In addition, PD63.14.1 requires that when such an order is made in favour of a party, that party must serve the order on the Comptroller within 14 days. Furthermore, if validity of the patent is challenged, the patentee (or other relevant party) should identify which claims of the patent are alleged to have independent validity as early as possible. [6. Statements of case (p. 3)]

question: In a registered designs appeal to the High Court from the Comptroller's decision, explain (a) whether permission to appeal is required, (b) to which court the appeal is assigned and under which Rule, (c) what notice must be served on the Comptroller, (d) what procedural steps the appellant must take within two weeks of lodging the appeal and regarding the setting down of the appeal, and (e) the availability and procedure for a paper hearing and the steps to pursue it if desired by the parties.
truth: The appeal lies only to the High Court and is governed by Part 52; permission to appeal is not required. Appeals in registered designs may be brought before the High Court or the Appointed Person, and appeals to the High Court are assigned to the Patents Court (Rule 63.16(2)). The Comptroller must be served with a Notice of Appeal (Rule 63.16(3)). The appellant, who has conduct of the appeal, should, within 2 weeks of lodging the appeal, contact the Chancery Listing Officer with a view to arranging a hearing date, and must ensure that the appeal is set down as soon as is reasonably practicable after service of the notice of appeal. The provisions about the service of skeleton arguments apply to appeals from the Comptroller. Appeals on paper only are possible if the parties desire; if the appellant is willing for the appeal to be heard on paper, he should contact the respondent and the UK Intellectual Property Office at the earliest opportunity to determine if such a procedure is agreed; if agreed, the Chancery Listing Office should be informed as soon as possible. The parties (and the Chancery Listing Officer if he/she desires) should liaise for early preparation of written submissions and bundles and provide the court with all necessary materials. [20. Appeals from the Comptroller (p. 12)]

question: In the Patents Court, to which track are actions allocated, which Part and PD govern case management, and what prefix has been used for claim numbers since October 2014?
truth: Actions proceeding in the Patents Court are allocated to the multi-track (Part 63.1(3)); case management is governed by Part 63.8 and PD63.5; since October 2014, claims issued in the Patents Court have claim numbers with the prefix HP-. [2. Allocation (p. 2)]

question: Under Annex D: Practice Statement: Listing of cases for trial in the Patents Court (p. 27), explain how a patent case estimated to last 6 days can be listed within 12 months, including: (1) the Trial Window framework for hearing times and how the Court may reduce a 6-day case to 5 days under its case management powers; (2) the conditions under which the Court can list the trial up to one month earlier than the applicable Trial Window without an expedition application; (3) the duties of the parties to consider and discuss trial dates; and (4) the circumstances in which a trial may be listed without reference to the availability of counsel.
truth: The Patents Court seeks to list patent cases for trial so that they may be heard within 12 months of issue. The starting point for listing is the current Trial Window advertised by the Chancery Division Listing Office, with patent trials categorized by estimated hearing time: 2–5 days; 5–10 days; and over 10 days (including pre-reading and preparation of closing submissions). A case estimated at 6 days falls within the 5–10 day band. The Court may exercise its case management powers under CPR rule 1.1 to deal with cases justly and at a proportionate cost, which may include allocating time between the parties and directing that a case estimated at 6 days be heard in 5 days to achieve a quicker listing. The Court may list a trial up to one month earlier than the applicable Trial Window if it will enable the case to be tried within 12 months (or shortly thereafter) without the need for any application for expedition. The obligations on the parties include: (a) starting to consider potential trial dates as soon as reasonably practicable after service of proceedings; and (b) discussing and attempting to agree trial dates with each other when seeking to agree directions for trial. Additionally, where listing the case earlier makes a significant difference to the waiting time and it will not cause significant prejudice to any party, cases may be listed without reference to the availability of counsel instructed by the parties. [Annex D: Practice Statement: Listing of cases for trial in the Patents Court (p. 27)]

question: Are the confidentiality undertakings in clause 3.1 symmetrical between the Discloser and the Recipient, and what are the exact obligations (A)-(E) that each party undertakes to protect Confidential Information, including how 'for the Purpose' and 'Representatives' are treated under these obligations?
truth: Yes. Clause 3.1 contemplates symmetrical confidentiality undertakings, meaning both the Discloser and the Recipient owe the same duties in relation to Confidential Information disclosed under the agreement. The exact obligations each party undertakes are: (A) to keep the Confidential Information secret and confidential; (B) to not use or exploit the Confidential Information in any way except for the Purpose; (C) to not disclose or make available any Confidential Information in whole or in part to any person to whom the Discloser has not disclosed the Confidential Information for the Purpose, except as expressly permitted by, and in accordance with, the agreement; (D) to apply the same security measures and degree of care to the Confidential Information as the party applies to its own confidential information, which the party warrants provides adequate protection from unauthorised disclosure, copying or use; and (E) to ensure that its Representatives who receive the Confidential Information comply with these obligations. These provisions ensure that access is limited to those who need to know for the Purpose, restrict use to the Purpose, and bind both parties and their Representatives to the same confidentiality standards. [3. The judges of the Patents Court (p. 2)]

question: In the Patents Court disclosure framework, when may a party provide a process and/or product description (PPD) instead of standard disclosure, and what are the detailed requirements governing its adequacy, the accompanying signed statement, handling of unverified aspects, the impact of Practice Direction 57AC on the written statement, and the consequences for omissions or inaccuracies (including costs and adjournments)? In your answer, include: (i) the role of Part 31 as modified by Rule 63.9, PD63.6.1-6.3, and Practice Direction 51U; (ii) the conditions under which 11.2 allows a PPD in place of standard disclosure; (iii) the joint responsibility of the parties at an early stage to determine the case's nature to ensure the PPD is adequate; (iv) the requirements in 11.4 for a signed written statement accompanying the PPD (parts (i)-(iii)); (v) the procedure under 11.5 when a party cannot verify all aspects of the PPD and the use of a disclosure list for the remainder; (vi) the statement in 11.5A about PD57AC not applying to the written state; and (vii) the practical consequences of material omissions or inaccuracies, including adjournment and adverse orders including costs. [11. Disclosure (p. 6)]
truth:
Answer:

- When a PPD may be used: A PPD may be provided instead of standard disclosure relating to processes or products alleged to infringe or otherwise relevant to the proceedings, where appropriate. This is stated in 11.2 and is subject to the overarching framework of Part 31 as modified by Rule 63.9, PD63.6.1-6.3, and Practice Direction 51U – Disclosure Pilot for the Business and Property Courts (11.1).

- Adequacy of the PPD: The PPD must be adequate to deal with the nature of the allegation advanced by the other party or parties. There is a joint responsibility at an early stage for the parties to determine the nature of the case so that the PPD is adequately tailored to that case (11.3).

- Accompanying signed statement: A PPD ought to be accompanied by a signed written statement which must (i) state that the person making the statement is personally acquainted with the facts to which the description relates; (ii) verify that the description is a true and complete description of the product or process; and (iii) acknowledge that the person may be required to attend court to be cross-examined on the contents of the description (11.4).

- Inability to verify all aspects (and the use of a disclosure list): If a party is not able to verify that the PPD is a true and complete description of all relevant aspects of its product or process (for example because it does not know how certain components work), the correct course is to verify the parts it can and to serve a disclosure list in relation to the remainder (11.5). The disclosure list may or may not contain any documents.

- PD57AC and the written statement: Practice Direction 57AC does not apply to the written state (11.5A). This means that the specific PD57AC formalities or requirements do not apply to the written statement accompanying the PPD (as stated in 11.5A).

- Consequences of omissions or inaccuracies: A material omission or inaccuracy in the PPD could lead to a costly adjournment and may result in adverse orders, including as to costs (11.4).

- Interplay with the disclosure framework: The obligations to provide disclosure under Part 31 are as modified by Rule 63.9, PD63.6.1-6.3, and as modified by Practice Direction 51U; the PPD framework is intended to operate within this modified regime and may be shaped by the Disclosure Pilot for the Business and Property Courts (11.1).

- Practical effect: Parties may be called upon to prove the PPD at trial, so accuracy and completeness are critical; failures to adhere to these requirements can cause delays and adverse cost consequences (11.4).

[11. Disclosure (p. 6)]

question: According to the Patents Court guidance in 8 Admissions (p. 5), what sequence of steps should a party take to identify and narrow non-issues through admissions (including when admissions may be made and what may be admitted), how does serving a notice to admit facts under Rule 32.18 assist in identifying points not in dispute and narrowing the real dispute (and thereby the scope of disclosure and witness/expert statements), what is the potential impact on costs in relation to the conduct of the parties (including whether it was reasonable to contest an issue under Rule 44.2(5)(b)), and what must be done if admissions change or if the independent validity of claims or the claims alleged to be infringed are altered?
truth: Adopt admissions early in defence or reply, for example admitting the acts complained of or that the article/process has features of a claim; in reply to a patentee, admission of prior publication of cited documents is possible. To identify points not in dispute, serve a notice to admit facts under Rule 32.18, which helps narrow the real dispute and thus limits the scope of disclosure and witness/expert statements. In deciding costs, the court may take into account the conduct of the parties, including whether it was reasonable to contest a particular issue (Rule 44.2(5)(b)). The position should be kept under constant review, and if admissions alter or if the identity of the claims said to have independent validity, or the claims alleged to be infringed, change, that information should be communicated forthwith to the other parties. [8. Admissions (p. 5)]

question: A party wishes to list an interim application in the Patents Court estimated to last 90 minutes and intends to fix a hearing date two weeks from today. Explain the proper procedure under 12 Arrangements for listing for listing this application, addressing: (a) whether the application qualifies as a 'short application' under 12.5, (b) the steps to arrange a hearing if the parties can agree dates, including how to contact the Court and any advertised lead times, (c) what to do if agreement cannot be reached and an appointment to fix is required, including the obligation to give 3 clear days' notice to all interested parties, (d) the obligation to consult the respondent before listing to avoid an adverse costs order, (e) the role and contact details of the Chancery Listing Officer and where the office is located, (f) the relevance of PD63.5 in this context (filing of documents and skeleton arguments), and (g) considerations if the matter involves urgent or without-notice applications under 12.6.
truth: The application is not a 'short application' under 12.5 because it is estimated to last 90 minutes, which exceeds the 1-hour threshold for short applications; short applications are those estimated to last no more than 1 hour and are typically heard before the normal court day starts (e.g., 9:30 or 10:00) and can be issued with the hearing date arranged at the Chancery Listing Office (12.5). For a non-short application, parties should first attempt to agree dates for trials or interim applications in accordance with 12.3, referencing the Chancery Listing Office's advertised lead times and, if possible, approaching the Court by email with agreed hearing dates. If the parties cannot agree and an appointment to fix is required, the applicant should first obtain an appointment from the Chancery Listing Officer and provide 3 clear days’ notice to all interested parties of the fixed date and time (12.3). Before listing, the applicant should consult with the proposed respondent about the subject-matter of the application; failure to properly consult prior to listing may lead to an adverse costs order (12.4). The Chancery Listing Officer is responsible for listing all work of the Patents Court and is based at the Rolls Building; the office hours are 10.00 am to 4.30 pm, with telephone number 020 7947 7717 and email ChanceryJudgesListing@justice.gov.uk (12.2). Attention is drawn to PD63.5, which governs the filing of documents and skeleton arguments (12.5 reference to PD63.5). If the matter involves urgent applications or applications without notice, a party should contact the Chancery Listing Office to discuss the appropriate procedure under 12.6 (12.6). The guidance in 12 Arrangements for listing thus requires careful coordination of agreement on dates, proper consultation with respondents, and use of the Chancery Listing Office for appointment and listing, with due regard to the listed office hours and contact details; all steps should conform to the Practice Statement: Listing of Cases for Trial in the Patents Court (Annex D) and the lead-time expectations. [12. Arrangements for listing (p. 7)]

question: According to the Patents Court guidance, what are the stated advantages of ADR, and under what condition may the Court stay proceedings to enable ADR?
truth: ADR has advantages including a significant saving of costs and providing parties with a wider range of solutions than can be offered by litigation. In an appropriate case, the Patents Court may stay the case for a specified period of time to encourage and enable the parties to use ADR. [9. Alternative Dispute Resolution ("ADR") (p. 6)]

question: In the Patents Court, if the judge is known in advance for a hearing, what are the precise steps and deadlines for lodging papers and the required media formats for submission, according to paragraphs 14.2 to 14.5 of '14. Documents and timetable (p. 9)'? Include the procedure if there is insufficient time to lodge hard copies, the deadline by which all relevant documents must be lodged, the judge’s USB requirement, and the reference to PD63.9 for trial timetable and bundle, as well as the bundling guidance in Annex E and Appendix 6 Chancery Guide.
truth: Where the judge is known, papers should be lodged directly with the judge’s clerk (14.2). If there is insufficient time to lodge hard copies before the deadline, documents of significance (notably skeleton arguments) should be supplied by email to the clerk of the judge concerned, followed up by clean hard copies (14.2). It is the joint responsibility of the parties to ensure that all relevant documents are lodged with the clerk by noon two days before the date fixed for hearing, unless the judge orders a different period or the guide prescribes otherwise (14.3). The judge requests that all important documents be supplied to him/her on a USB stick in a format convenient for the judge’s use (typically current or recent version of Microsoft Word for Windows or a text-searchable PDF); these USB materials usually include skeleton arguments, important patents, prior art, witness statements and expert reports (14.4). Prior to trial, parties must comply with PD63.9 concerning the provision of a trial timetable, trial bundle and reading guide for the judge; the timetable should be detailed, setting out witness evidence times and any days a witness is unavailable (14.5). In addition, the guidance in Annex E on Standard Trial Bundles and the general guidance in Appendix 6 Chapter 21 of the Chancery Guide (paras 21.34–21.72) apply, with non-compliance potentially leading to cost penalties (14.1). [14. Documents and timetable (p. 9)]

question: According to 2.1, 2.3, 2.4 and 2.5 of the King's Bench Division guidance on litigants in person, describe: (a) how a litigant in person is defined and how the rules apply to LiPs in relation to represented parties, including any leading authority cited regarding standard of compliance; (b) the obligations of LiPs and represented parties in terms of mutual respect; (c) the address for service requirements for claimants and defendants, and the consequences of failing to notify changes of address; (d) the public accessibility of documents and the relevant CPR/PD references; and (e) the general duty of all parties to litigation as stated in 2.6.
truth:
Definition and application: A litigant in person (LiP) is a person who brings or defends legal proceedings without legal representation. The rules of practice and procedure apply to litigants in person in the same way as they apply to represented parties, and the provisions of this guide also apply to LiPs. The Court will have regard to the fact that a party is unrepresented (see CPR3.1A) but it will not usually apply a lower standard of compliance with rules, PDs or orders of the court, as illustrated by Barton v Wright Hassall LLP [2018] UKSC 12. 

Respectful conduct: Represented parties must treat LiPs with consideration and respect at all times, and LiPs must show consideration and respect to their opponents and to the court. 

Address for service: A LiP must provide an address for service in England or Wales. For claimants, the address is required in the claim form or other initiating document; for defendants, it is provided in the acknowledgment of service form sent to the court. Any change of address must be notified in writing to the Central Office and to all other parties, otherwise important communications such as notices of hearing dates may not reach the LiP (though they are likely to be treated as having been received). 

Public access to documents: The public is entitled to obtain copies of some documents filed at court unless the court has ordered otherwise. See online public search, open justice, anonymity, confidential documents, non-disclosure orders and Tomlin orders, and CPR 5.4B, 5.4C and PD5A for further guidance. 

Duty of all parties: It is the duty of all parties to litigation, whether represented or not, to comply with the rules, practice directions and orders of the court. [2. Litigants in person (p. 23)]

question: A landlord seeks possession of vacant commercial premises occupied by a group of trespassers who have begun to obstruct access and have announced plans to escalate into a large-scale, potentially violent protest. Police indicate a substantial risk of public disturbance and there is a real prospect of serious harm to persons and property if the occupation continues, requiring immediate attention. The landlord intends to issue the claim in the High Court (Kings Bench or Chancery Division) rather than the County Court. Assess whether issuing in the High Court is appropriate under CPR 55.3(2) and Annex 3, and explain: (i) what criteria justify High Court proceedings in trespasser possession claims, (ii) what the certificate filed with the claim must contain and its formal requirements (including the “statement of truth”), (iii) how the guidance in PD55A applies to trespassers, and (iv) what alternative path would be typical if the threshold for High Court involvement is not met.
truth:
Answer:
- General rule and exceptional pathway: Annex 3 explains that, in most possession claims against trespassers, the claim should be issued in the County Court. A claim may be issued in the High Court only in exceptional cases, where the circumstances justify it under CPR 55.3(2) and related Practice Direction. The High Court option is available if the claimant files with the claim a certificate stating the reasons for bringing the claim in the High Court, and the certificate must be signed with a statement of truth (CR 55.3(2); the certificate mechanism is expressly referenced in Annex 3).
- PD55A guidance and trespassers: PD55A para. 1.3(3) identifies one circumstance that may justify starting the claim in the High Court: when the claim is against trespassers and there is a substantial risk of public disturbance or of serious harm to persons or property which properly require immediate attention. The note also states that, unless there is real urgency, the High Court will rarely be the suitable venue. PD55A para. 1.6, however, has no relevance to claims against trespassers (i.e., its provisions do not apply to trespasser possession claims).
- Application to the given scenario: The scenario presents a substantial risk of public disturbance and potential serious harm to persons and property, with a need for immediate attention. If the risk is indeed substantial and requires immediate action to prevent harm or disruption, this scenario could satisfy the exceptional High Court criterion under PD55A para. 1.3(3). The decision to proceed in the High Court would depend on demonstrating that the risk is truly substantial and urgent; otherwise, the default pathway remains the County Court.
- Division concerns: Claims may be issued in either the King’s Bench or the Chancery Division of the High Court; the annex does not require the land to be subject to a charge to issue in the Chancery Division (it explicitly notes this for claims under PD55A and clarifies that PD55A para. 1.6 is not relevant to trespassers). The practical choice between divisions would depend on the nature of the case and procedural considerations, but the trespasser context is governed by the high threshold for urgency.
- Certificate requirements: Under CPR 55.3(2), the claimant may issue in the High Court only if a certificate is filed with the claim stating the reasons for bringing the claim in the High Court. The certificate must be signed with a statement of truth. The content should articulate the grounds under PD55A para. 1.3(3) (i.e., substantial risk of public disturbance or serious harm to persons or property requiring immediate attention) and explain why the High Court is warranted given the urgency and risk profile, including supporting evidence or anticipated evidence (e.g., police risk assessments, imminent threats, potential for widespread disruption).
- Practical considerations and limitations: The High Court will rarely be suitable unless there is real urgency. Even where substantial risk exists, the claimant must satisfy the court that the risk requires immediate attention and that the High Court’s involvement is justified as exceptional. If the risk is not truly urgent or substantial, the claimant should proceed in the County Court.
- Summary guidance for the scenario: Given a substantial, immediate risk of public disturbance and serious harm to persons or property, the claim may be justified in the High Court if the certificate convincingly sets out the urgency and grounds under PD55A para. 1.3(3) and is supported by evidence. If these conditions cannot be satisfied, the County Court remains the appropriate forum. The land’s lack of a charge and choice of division are secondary to the urgency criterion. The certificate must be filed with the claim and bear a statement of truth.
- References: CPR 55.3(2); PD55A para. 1.3(3); PD55A para. 1.6 (not relevant to trespassers). [Annex 3. Possession claims against trespassers]

question: Under the Media and Communications List (MAC List) rules, outline the procedure for transferring a claim into or out of the MAC List, including (i) who may initiate the transfer, (ii) the latest deadline for making the transfer application, (iii) the notification duties when seeking transfer into the MAC List, and (iv) the consent requirements, particularly where the claim has already been issued in the Chancery Division.
truth: A transfer into or out of the MAC List may be effected by an application or by the court’s own initiative (see PD53A). Any transfer application should be made promptly and, at the latest, by the first case management conference. If the application is for transfer into the MAC List, the applicant must give notice of the application to the court or list in which the claim is proceeding, and the MAC List Judge will not make an order for transfer until such notice and any applicable consent have been given. If the claim has been issued in the Chancery Division, consent of the Chancellor of the High Court must be obtained for transfer. The MAC List is a specialist list of the High Court and claims are heard in the Royal Courts of Justice. [17. The Media and Communications List (p. 143)]

question: Explain the procedural steps and evidentiary rules for a defendant who wishes to dispute the suitability of the Part 8 procedure after filing an acknowledgment of service, including how such dispute is conveyed, what evidence must be filed, and how extensions of time for evidentiary compliance may be obtained.
truth: If a defendant wishes to challenge the suitability of the Part 8 procedure after filing an acknowledgment of service, they must: (i) state the dispute in the acknowledgment of service and give reasons for the objection (CPR 8.6); (ii) file any written evidence on which they intend to rely at the same time as their acknowledgment of service (CPR 8.5); (iii) be aware that Part 8 claims are normally disposed of on written evidence without cross-examination, with witness statements generally sufficient to define the issues (CPR 8.2); (iv) recognise that a defendant is not entitled to take part in the hearing without the court’s permission if they do not file an acknowledgment of service, so timely filing is essential to participate (CPR 8.5–8.6); (v) understand that if extensions of time are needed for evidentiary compliance, extensions up to 28 days may be agreed in writing between the parties; longer extensions require a Part 23 application to the court and will be heard by a Master (CPR 8.7); and (vi) expect the court to grant a reasonable extension where appropriate, with parties encouraged to cooperate, recognising that the time limits for defendants to provide evidence may place a significant burden (CPR 8.7). The framework for whether Part 8 is appropriate is set by Rule 8.1(2) and Practice Direction 49E, which identify the types of claims and the cases where Part 8 must be used (8.1; Practice Direction 49E). [8. Part 8 - Alternative procedure for claims (p. 68)]

question: Explain the legal status of the King's Bench Division Guide and its relationship to the Civil Procedure Rules (CPR) and Practice Directions (PD), including the obligations it imposes on litigants and advisers regarding CPR compliance, and describe the requirements for modifying standard forms of order, particularly the display of the Royal Arms.
truth: The Guide is an official document prepared under the direction of the Senior Master, acting under the authority of the President of the King's Bench Division, intended to explain the work and practice of the King's Bench Division with particular regard to proceedings started in the Central Office. It must be read with the Civil Procedure Rules and the supporting Practice Directions; litigants and their advisers are responsible for acquainting themselves with the CPR, and the Guide is not a substitute for the CPR. The CPR, PDs and pre-action protocols and forms are available on the gov.uk website. Standard forms of order used in the KBD may be found at King's Bench forms; forms can be modified as individual cases require, but a modified form must contain at least as full information as would have been given if the original form had been used; when modified, the modified form must contain a complete Royal Arms, and the format for the Royal Arms on modified forms need not follow the format used on the listed forms. The Guide is intended to be reviewed and updated at regular intervals. It does not have the status of a Practice Direction nor the force of law, but parties using the KBD are expected to act in accordance with the Guide to assist with achieving the CPR overriding objective. It is assumed throughout the Guide that the litigant intends to proceed in the Royal Courts of Justice. [1. Introduction (p. 15)]

question: Under para 21 of the GLO guidance, what is the prerequisite for a claim to be entered on the Group Register, and at the point of issue what CE-File notification must the claimant's solicitors provide to link the claim to an existing or prospective GLO, including the specific lead claim reference and the method by which notification may be made?
truth: A claim must be issued before it can be entered on the Group Register. At the point of issue, the claimant's solicitors must notify the court that the claim is subject to an existing GLO or an application for a GLO, and provide the lead claim number (or the claim first issued if no lead claim has been identified) so that all related claims can be linked and managed together. This notification is to be made in CE-File, either by including a filing comment or by filing a letter when the claim is issued, in accordance with the Practice Direction. Claims are issued via CE-File in the usual way. [21. Group Litigation Orders "GLOs" (p. 167)]

question: Identify all Contracting Authorities listed in Annex 10 as having acceded to the 2005 Hague Convention on Choice of Court Agreements, and state the date on which the Convention entered into force for each such Authority.
truth: Denmark and Mexico are the Contracting Authorities recorded as having acceded to the 2005 Hague Convention on Choice of Court Agreements. question: Within the Blank Form of Order (Annex 9), identify the sequence and function of the introductory lines preceding the operative provisions, namely the heading and case identifiers, the recital(s) 'UPON considering the' and 'AND UPON the court noting that/hearing', and the operative clause 'IT IS ORDERED that', and explain how the actual substantive directions are to be formatted within this form.
truth: The form starts with the court and case identifiers: 'IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE', the Claim No., 'KING'S BENCH DIVISION', and the parties listed under 'Claimant' and 'Defendant', with the heading 'ORDER' signaling that the document is a court order. Following the introductory lines, the recitals 'UPON considering the' and 'AND UPON the court noting that/hearing' function as preconditions or grounds for making the order, indicating that the court has considered the application and either noted facts or heard submissions. The operative portion is then introduced by the explicit formula 'IT IS ORDERED that:', which marks the transition from recitals to the substantive directions. The operative part in this blank form is represented by the enumerated items '1. Text of order' and '2. Text of order', which in a filled‑in order would contain the court’s substantive directions or orders, each forming a separate limb of the order. The line 'Dated this day of 202x' provides the formal dating of the order, with the day to be filled in and the year shown as a placeholder. The structure reflects standard UK civil procedure practice whereby the order is prefaced by consideration/notice language and concluded with a clearly numbered operative clause. [Annex 9. Blank Form of Order]

question: Explain the regime under CPR21 for a claim brought by or concerning a child or protected party, detailing: (i) when a litigation friend is required, (ii) who may act as a litigation friend and how they are appointed or replaced by the court (including the court’s powers under CPR21.7), (iii) the steps a solicitor must take if they have concerns about the litigation friend’s conduct, (iv) the process for someone to act as a litigation friend without a court order (including Form N235), (v) the Official Solicitor’s role when no suitable person is available and the conditions that must be satisfied for their appointment, and (vi) the effect of CPR21.10(1) on settlements or compromises or interim payments in respect of a child or protected party, including the PD25B regime for interim payments.
truth: A child or protected party requires a litigation friend in order to conduct litigation; any steps taken on behalf of a child or protected party without a litigation friend are not valid unless the court orders otherwise (CPR21.1). The court has the power under CPR21.7 to appoint a litigation friend, to change the litigation friend, and to prevent a person from acting as a litigation friend; if there is concern that a litigation friend is not acting properly, a solicitor for the child or protected party should notify the court and may apply under CPR21.7 to remove or replace the litigation friend (CPR21.2–CPR21.7). Where a person may be a litigation friend without a court order, they must file a certificate of suitability in Practice Form N235 (N235: File a certificate of suitability to be a litigation friend) (CPR21.3). If there is no-one suitable to act as a litigation friend, the Official Solicitor may be approached to act; the Official Solicitor will only act where there is no other suitable person and there is confirmation that their legal costs will be paid; the court may, if necessary, consider ordering another party to act (CPR21.4). No settlement or compromise or payment in respect of a claim by or against a child or protected party will be valid unless and until the court has approved it (CPR21.10(1)); this prohibition applies even if the settlement is reached under Part 36 and even if the settlement concerns only one aspect of the claim. The rule also applies to interim payments, and permission of the court must be sought before any voluntary interim payment is made (PD25B para 1.2).
